channel.title: Advanced sampling with Auxy and Ableton link
channel.description:
H’ooookay so. I would like to preface this by saying I am NOT a production guru. I’ve been around the block a few times with iOS music production though, minus the intermittent now and again where I use a “big boy” DAW, I’ve been doing the majority of my production on iOS for about seven years now. I want to touch base on sampling in Auxy and how Ableton link can facilitate this. You do not need a computer to do this, just other Ableton Link enabled apps that can also “Copy to” Auxy.
Firstly, make sure you have either blocs wave or Groovebox by Novation/ampify. If you don’t have these two apps get the fricc on it, you’re crazy. Once you have these both, open Auxy, set up a new project (or open existing, whatever), set your tempo and enable Ableton Link from the nut menu. It’ll turn on and be connected to 0 apps. Go out of Auxy and open up blocs wave, for example. Start a new project there and from the deck of cards menu go into settings and enable Ableton Link there. Now. If blocs wave (or Auxy) show 1 app connected, success! The apps are now sharing tempo information. You have to start play independently in each app but the playheads line up. If you don’t see how this is incredibly useful, allow me to demonstrate:
You have a drum loop or synth playing in Auxy. You back out of that, plop down percussion in blocs wave and it tempo syncs perfectly. Maybe you nudge the tempo around a bit, and now you like what you hear. Making sure your blocs wave loop is under ten seconds, export your session to wave file and “Copy to” Auxy. Now, go back to Auxy, perhaps organize a bit using the Files app and you can load what you were playing live in blocs wave as a loop triggered in a drum channel. It will be perfectly tempo synced.
Obviously, once you render your export from blocs wave (or wherever) and change tempo, you’d have to fix your sample source and re-export at your new tempo.
Boy I wish I knew how to make a video and had the bleepin time to demonstrate to you folks, but anyway, this should big time help you in your quest for sample ease of use.
I hope I get a gold medal because I typed all of this out on a friccin iPhone SE my thumbs are killing me. Anyway, ICS out. Happy looping!!

item.description:
Np! I keep seeing the same questions here so I figured I’d try to shed a little light. Also, and I know you know this already, but DAWs like Live and Reason also support Link. So as long as all devices are on the same network you can link up iPhones, iPads etc to a pc/Mac running Reason or Live, possibly others.

Fun fact: Ableton Link seems to replace WIST. Anyone remember that?
